text:
Security is more fragmented than ever. New acronyms (SSE, CTEM, CIEM, SIEM, SOAR, CNAPP, ITDR, DSPM‚Ä¶) and categories keep piling up, and the labels often make the landscape more confusing instead of clearer. Companies that look competitive on the surface are often tackling very different problems.

The kill chain provides a better lens. Every attack follows the same sequence: reconnaissance, delivery, exploitation, command and control, lateral movement, and exfiltration. Defenders can break the chain at any of these stages. When seen this way, it becomes clear that many products  are aimed at different weak points in the sequence. 

AI now accelerates this dynamic. Attackers use it to generate zero days, phishing at scale, mutate malware faster than signatures can catch it, and scan attack surfaces at machine speed. Defenders cannot bolt AI onto legacy tools. They need AI-native systems built from the ground up to learn, adapt, and automate. The platform shift is already here.

The north star remains simple. The winners will be the products that break the chain earlier, faster, and collapse point tools into comprehensive solutions that eliminate attack paths altogether.

For early-stage founders one of THE most important parts of your GTM motion needs to be understanding the HIGH-PRIORITY PROBLEM(S) you solve for your prospect. However, even that is too much of a simplification...


Because when you've mapped out your key stakeholders, you need to understand the problem you're solving, the answer to the question 'What's in it for me?' for EVERY SINGLE ONE OF THEM.

In your deal you will have an Economic Buyer, a Champion, User Buyers and Technical Buyers, and you need every one of the to say YES (or at the very least from your User and Technical Buyers, not a 'no') to get your deal done.

And for them to say YES, you need to be solving a high-priority problem for each them. This problem might be a different by stakeholder, or might be the same problem, just seen through a different lens.

Obviously, for different solutions those problems will be different, but there are some commonalities on the types of things they will usually care about.

‚û°Ô∏è User Buyers - for your User Buyers, the problem is usually around features and functionality. What does your product do that makes their lives much easier, better, more efficient, more effective?

‚û°Ô∏è Technical Buyers - usually for Technical Buyers, they want to know you don't break anything or that you're in line with whatever compliance infrastructure they have. Essentially, you want your Technical Buyers not to say 'No!'

‚û°Ô∏è Champion - you're going to ask your Champion to advocate for your solution. They're going to be putting their reputation on the line for you, and may even be putting their jobs on the line, so you really need to be solving a HIGH-PRIORITY problem for them. For it to be a high-priority it usually needs to be related to their targets / KPIs /OKRs - so you need to understand what these are and show how your solution helps them hit these targets in a way they cannot do without you.

‚û°Ô∏è Economic Buyer - as your EB is likely more senior, they usually care more about strategic projects as well as the cold hard cash of the commercial benefit of your solution. So you need to understand what these strategic projects are, and how your solution gets them to where they need to be, in a way they cannot do with their incumbent solutions. That last part is key, EBs are usually change adverse, so you need to show how hard - or ideally impossible - it will be for them to hit their targets without you.

And commercial benefits for EBs come down to reducing costs, maximising revenue and reducing risk. So how does your solution move these needles? Even if they don't have a target for these, EBs will always be thinking how they will justify the use of their budget in buying your solution. And there's no better justification than a rock solid ROI.

Much more on this in our booklet Value Creation Explained where we go through the Value Pyramid of understanding the PROBLEM you solve and the VALUE you create for every one of your stakeholders.

We ended on a philosophical note: if future systems begin to reason without producing human-readable tokens, how will we recognize their intelligence or monitor their potential misalignment? We‚Äôre still in the early innings of agentic AI and the era of experimentation. There‚Äôs never been a better moment to dive in.

Every person in technology should know the story of Stuxnet, the most complicated yet beautiful malware ever created.

A state-sponsored piece of software that made a serious dent to Iran‚Äôs nuclear program, completely disconnected from any network, and proved: cyberweapons don‚Äôt only affect cyberspace.

It was one of the stories told by a college CS professor that got me into Computer Science. Here's the full story:


In 2010, Iranian nuclear engineers faced a nightmare. Their centrifuges kept failing. 1000s of them. But every dashboard showed perfect operations.

They were staring at the work of nation-state programmers, widely believed to be the US, who‚Äôd spent years crafting it. Not a bomb, but a very sophisticated 500KB file that could jump air gaps and destroy infrastructure.

The code was a masterpiece: 4 zero-day exploits with stolen certificates from Realtek & JMicron, modules in multiple languages. Someone had reverse-engineered Siemens‚Äô proprietary Step7 industrial systems that the centrifuges ran on to hijack the programmable logic controllers (PLC) when new code was deployed.

But how do you infect a facility with no internet? The Natanz enrichment plant in Iran was air-gapped! Stuxnet first hit Windows machines across the globe via USB drives, using an LNK vulnerability that triggered just by viewing files. It was patient. On each machine, it checked: Are you running Siemens Step7 software? No? Sleep and spread.

Eventually, some engineer somewhere would carry their laptop to work. Maybe they‚Äôd update control systems. Maybe they‚Äôd check diagnostics. They‚Äôd plug in their USB, and Stuxnet would finally see what it was looking for: Siemens controllers running specific configurations.

It would burrow into the PLCs, inject its payload between legitimate code blocks, and begin its real work: recording, lying, and destroying. All while reporting that everything was perfectly fine.

The attack had surgical precision: it only attacked controllers with 33+ frequency converters, running at specific speeds, controlling specific centrifuges. The rest of the million infected computers were just carriers.

It took Iran 4 years to fully understand what hit them. By then, Stuxnet had set their nuclear program back years. Not with sanctions. Not with bombs. But with code.

Many companies talk about implementing data contracts and shifting left, but Zakariah S. and the team at Glassdoor have actually done it. 

In an article published earlier today, the Glassdoor Data Platform team goes in-depth about how they have started driving data quality from the source through data contracts, proactive monitoring/observability, and Data DevOps. 

Here's a great quote from the article on the value of Shifting Left:

"This approach offers many benefits, but the top four we‚Äôve observed are:

Data¬†Quality¬†by¬†Design: Incorporating data quality checks early in the lifecycle helps prevent bad data from entering production systems.

Fewer¬†Downstream¬†Breakages: By resolving potential issues closer to the source, the entire data pipeline becomes more resilient and less susceptible to cascading failures.

Stronger¬†Collaboration: Equipping product engineers with tools, frameworks, and guidelines to generate high-quality data nurtures a closer partnership between data producers and consumers.

Cost¬†&¬†Time¬†Efficiency: Preventing bad data is significantly cheaper than diagnosing and fixing it after propagating across multiple systems.
These were the foundational principles upon which our motivation for shifting left was achieved."

Glassdoor achieved this through six primary technology investments:

Data Contracts (Gable.ai): Define clear specifications for fields, types, and constraints, ensuring product engineers are accountable for data quality from the start.

Static Code Analysis (Gable.ai): Integrated with GitLab/GitHub and Bitrise to catch and block problematic data changes before they escalate downstream.

LLMs for Anomaly Detection (Gable.ai): Identify subtle issues (e.g., swapped field names) that may not violate contracts but could lead to data inconsistencies.

Schema Registry (Confluent): Screens incoming events, enforcing schema validation and directing invalid data to dead-letter queues to keep pipelines clean.

Real-time Monitoring (DataDog): Provides continuous feedback loops to detect and resolve issues in real time.

Write-Audit-Publish (WAP) / Blue-Green Deployment: Ensures each data batch passes through a staging area before being promoted to production, isolating risks before they impact downstream consumers.

"By addressing the psychological dimension of trust through shared responsibility, transparent validation, and confidence-building checks, we‚Äôre scaling to petabytes without compromising our data‚Äôs essential sense of faith. Ultimately, this combination of technical rigor and cultural awareness empowers us to build resilient, trustworthy data systems ‚Äî one contract, one check, and one validation at a time."

One thing that's becoming abundantly clear is that the "AI application" companies that recognize the importance of the shift from good prompt engineering to great context engineering (i.e. how to best model, enrich, and retrieve domain specific context) early, will be the ones with the best shot at winning their categories. 

- The strongest apps will understand the underlying data most precisely and build rich affordances + pipelines to feedback user generated metadata into their living, breathing data model.
- The data model (or ontology as Palantir would call it) can become a compounding asset. There has to be a semantic foundation underpinning it - a model of entities, relationships between them, and rich metadata that shapes how information should be prioritized and interpreted. 
- Metadata ends up being the biggest source of unlock in today's systems vs. an arguable nice to have in deterministic software. How will you accumulate and structure interesting metadata?
- Advanced systems are evolving into architectures that combine dense embedding retrieval with symbolic filters, graph traversal, metadata-aware reranking and summarization. They understand not only what to retrieve but why it‚Äôs relevant and how it fits into a broader reasoning chain.
- This shift is especially important for agentic systems. Agents need to ‚Äúshow their work‚Äù and expose what information they retrieved, how it informed their reasoning, and which evidence supports their decisions. That transparency isn‚Äôt a UX layer. It depends on structured, contextualized data under the hood. Provenance and replayable reasoning both emerge from sound data modeling.
- The most effective applications also close the loop between user behavior and retrieval performance. Every edit, clarification or correction becomes signal for context quality. With time, rerankers, query reformulators, and embedding clusters evolve to reflect real usage. 
- If done correctly, your app can literally do things that others' cant. It can answer many, many net new questions and will of course win on the most important enterprise (purchasing) metric today - time to trust.

text:
"I burned $800K of my exit money in 18 months trying to angel invest."
A successful founder confessed this to me last week, devastated after backing just 6 startups with oversized checks.

This isn't unusual. 

Assuming you make it to the next level, exit your company and don't over-dilute (see my other posts), there's a new challenge that awaits you on the other side. 

The desire to angel invest.

I've watched newly-wealthy founders burn through millions faster in angel investing than they ever did building their own startups.

After watching dozens of new angels destroy their hard-earned exits, 
Here's the framework I now share with everyone:

Angel investing is a portfolio construction game, not a stock-picking contest.

Check out the math:
- Even professional VCs expect 80%+ of investments to return 0X at the seed stage
- Another 10%-15% might return 1-2X (barely keeping pace with inflation)
- Your entire portfolio return depends on the 10%-5% of outliers

Yet most new angels do this:

- Invest $50K-$100K in 3-5 companies they "really believe in"
- Get deeply emotionally invested in each one
- Panic when 2-3 inevitably struggle
- Burn out on angel investing entirely

The founder who lost $800K? 

He ignored all advice about check size and diversification, convinced he could "pick winners" based on his own success.

Here's my advice to every new angel:

- Set aside a fixed pool (say $500K if you've just exited)
- Divide it into equal allocations ($25K x 20 companies)
- Expect to deploy over 3-4 years minimum
- Never, ever deviate from your allocation size
- Assume every check is a lottery ticket that will likely return 0X

One successful founder-turned-angel told me: 

"The moment I started treating this like buying 20 lottery tickets instead of 'investing in winners,' my stress disappeared and I actually started enjoying helping founders."

For founders seeking angel money: This is why your angels might be generalists who can only help in limited ways. The smart ones are playing a diversification game.

And for new angels: If you're not comfortable writing off your entire angel portfolio, you're not ready to start. 

The math is unforgiving - your expected return depends on your willingness to make enough bets and diversify.

Your goal isn't picking winners. 

It's buying enough tickets to ensure you don't miss the one outlier that returns your entire fund.
